solution.tex: Statement: Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of holomorphic functions defined on a region $\Omega$. Then $\mathcal{F}$ is normal if and only if $\mathcal{F}$ is locally bounded. First, let's recall the Arzela Ascoli theorem (AA). That is that $\mathcal{F}$ is normal if and only if two properties: 1) for each $z_0\in\Omega$, the set $\{f(z_0)|f\in\mathcal{F}\}$ has compact closure in $\Omega$, 2) $\mathcal{F}$ is equicontinuous at every point $z_0\in\Omega$. Equicontinuous at $z_0$ means that for all $\epsilon>0$ there is a $\delta>0$ such that for all $f\in\mathcal{F}$ and for all $z\in\Omega$ with $|z-z_0|<\delta$, $|f(z)-f(z_0)|<\epsilon$. To be locally bounded at $z_0\in\Omega$, there have to be constants $M,r>0$ such that for all $z\in\Omega$ with $|z-z_0|< r$, for all $f\in\mathcal{F}$, then $|f(z)|< M$. Now to work on the theorem. Suppose $\mathcal{F}$ is normal and let $z_0$ be an element of $\Omega$. Then the result of Arzela-Ascoli theorem holds. Let $M$ be such that $|f(z_0)|\leq M$ for all $f$, this is result 1) of AA. By result 2), there is a $\delta>0$ such that $|f(z)-f(z_0)|< M+\epsilon$ for all $f\in\mathcal{F}$ and for all $z\in B_{\delta}(z_0)$. This shows that $\mathcal{F}$ is locally bounded at $z_0$, with the constants $M+\epsilon$ and $\delta$. Now suppose that $\mathcal{F}$ is locally bounded at all points in $\Omega$. This assumption immediately shows part 1) of AA, because bounded subsets of $\mathbb{C}$ are relatively compact. We need to show $\mathcal{F}$ is equicontinuous at $z_0$. Take the constants $M,r$ from the definition of locally bounded, also choose $r$ small enough so that $\overline{B_r(z_0)}\subset\Omega$. Then for all $z\in B_r(z_0)$ and all $f\in\mathcal{F}$, we have asusmed that $|f(z)|\leq M$. Let $\epsilon>0$ be given. Let $z\in\Omega$ with $|z-z_0|<\frac{r}{2}$. Let $\gamma$ be the circle $|z-z_0|=r$. By Cauchy's integral formula applied to arbitrary $f\in\mathcal{F}$, \[|f(z)-f(z_0)|=\left|\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma\frac{f(w)}{w-z}dw-\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma\frac{f(w)}{w-z_0}dw\right|=\frac{1}{2\pi}\left|\int_\gamma\frac{f(w)(z-z_0)}{(w-z)(w-z_0)}dw\right|\] \[\leq\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma\left|\frac{f(w)(z-z_0)}{(w-z)(w-z_0)}\right||dw|.\] Here we will use some bounds. $|f(w)|\leq M$, $|w-z_0|=r$, and $|w-z|\geq\frac{r}{2}$. Thus \[\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma\left|f(w)(z-z_0)\frac{1}{w-z}\frac{1}{w-z_0}\right||dw|\leq\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_\gamma M|z-z_0|\frac{2}{r}\frac{1}{r}|dw|=\frac{M}{\pi r^2}|z-z_0|\int_\gamma|dw|=\frac{2M}{r}|z-z_0|<\frac{3M}{r}|z-z_0|.\] Therefore if we choose $\delta$ to be $0<\delta<\frac{r\epsilon}{2}$ (so this whole argument applies) and less than $\frac{r}{3M}$, then we have shown equicontinuous and therefore (by AA) normal.
